title: Climbing the Heap
lender: Friends of Freeport and Frank Passalaqua
description: Friends of Freeport and other groups helped their neighbors and friends clean up after Sandy, work that continues today.  It took Frank Passalaqua of Baldwin two weeks to recover from the storm.
subject: Hurricane Sandy
rights: Friends of Freeport and Frank Passalaqua

title: 1991 Nor'easter

title: Sandy Damage in Freeport and Seaford
lender: Long Island Studies Institute and Peter Kopher
description:
The streets of Freeport and Seaford became rivers during Sandy.  Peter and Sally Kopher’s houseboat was one of the victims.  
“The house barge got picked up 3 or 4 feet, went over the top of the pilings that we’re secured to, and was pushed inland about 50 yards.  The floating dock tailed along behind it the whole time.  We were bow to bow with our neighbors’ barge instead of side by side.” -  Peter Kopher. Photo by Ben Jackson.
subject: Hurricane Sandy

title: Boardwalk
lender: Photographs by Dem Lom, Courtesy of Long Island Studies Institute
description: “There was a very weird dynamic that you only had to drive 15 minutes away and there were people who didn’t have to deal with any of this.  My grandmother’s house had four feet of water in the basement.”  -  State Senator Todd Kaminsky
subject: Hurricane Sandy

title: Beach replenishment
lender: Michael Busch, Great South Bay Images
subject: Hurricane Protection; Coastal Zone Management
rights: Michael Busch, Great South Bay Images

title: Wood Crib
lender: Ben Jackson Construction and Anthony Rector
description: To elevate a home, Ben Jackson’s Construction in Freeport and contractor Anthony Rector need helical piles, wood cribs and steel beams.  Bay house owner Brian Warasila also used helical piles for his house after it was moved in 2000 due to erosion.  Courtesy Ben Jackson Construction and Anthony Rector.
rights: Ben Jackson Construction and Anthony Rector

title: Hurricane Gloria Newsday
description: Bay Houses during Hurricane Gloria
subject: Hurricane Gloria

title: Far Rockaway Beach Replenishment
description: Image of beach replishment efforts in the Far Rockaways following Hurricane Irene.
subject: Hurricane Irene

title: Fort Pond Bay Pre Hurricane of 1938
description: “Prior to the Hurricane of 1938, the entire village of Montauk was located on the shores of Fort Pond Bay.  There were pound nets, all around the perimeter of the bay.  That was where my grandfather bought into the fresh fish business. And the Hurricane of 1938 came along, and rearranged the landscape.  The commercial fleet gradually relocated to Montauk Harbor, where it is today, and the village of Montauk moved over to the south side, on the ocean side, where it is today.”  - Chip Duryea, Montauk Resident
subject: Long Island Express; 1938 Hurricane

title: Fort Pond Bay Post Hurricane of 1938
description: “Prior to the Hurricane of 1938, the entire village of Montauk was located on the shores of Fort Pond Bay.  There were pound nets, all around the perimeter of the bay.  That was where my grandfather bought into the fresh fish business. And the Hurricane of 1938 came along, and rearranged the landscape.  The commercial fleet gradually relocated to Montauk Harbor, where it is today, and the village of Montauk moved over to the south side, on the ocean side, where it is today.”  - Chip Duryea, Montauk Resident
subject: Long Island Express; 1938 Hurricane

title: Hatch Photo
lender: Trap doors, or hatches, helped bay houses from being lifted up and carried away by the current during storms and high tides.
subject: Bay Houses; Tangible Cultural Heritage

title: Hurricane of 1938 Freeport Damage
description: Freeport and other south shore communities suffered major damage during the 1938 hurricane.
subject: Long Island Express;1938 Hurricane

title: Three Architecture Models
lender: New York Institute of Technology; Robert Cody and Matthew Altwicker; Nancy Solomon
description: Architecture students at New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury were asked to design models and plans for structures and communities that could withstand another superstorm or hurricane.  Student contributors: Arkadiusz Chrobak, Marissa Marzullo, Shivanie Muneshwar, Vanessa Rocha, Eric Jakob, Minh Nguyen, Waisuddin Aziz, and Thomas Meade.
rights: New York Institute of Technology; Nancy Solomon

title: Looking Back Objects
lender: Sag Harbor Whaler's Church; Long Island Traditions
description: On September 17, 1938 the “Long Island Express” hurricane struck Westhampton Beach.  The Raynor family and others like them had no warning.  Houses were destroyed, but some furnishings survived, including the clock featured in this image.
subject: Long Island Express; 1938 Hurricane

title: Bay House Display
lender: Long Island Maritime Museum; Don Pollera; Baunlich
description: In addition to the Bay House models built by Jeff Blossom, you can see a painting of the Byrne-Van Wicklen Bay House, built c. 1947, which survived Sandy, painted by Daniel Pollera, a renowned artist. A piece of the Jones Beach park railing detached during the storm and floated to the bay house.
subject: Bay Houses; Tangible Cultural Heritage

title: What Would You Bring?
description: Visitors to the Long Island Maritime Museum were asked to describe what they would choose to bring along in the case of an emergency evacuation. Objects from their responses were displayed as part of the exhibit.
subject: Emergency Management

title: Long Beach Boardwalk Railing
description: The Long Beach boardwalk, originally built in 1914, was destroyed by Sandy, along with parts of the Jones Beach boardwalk.
subject: Hurricane Sandy

title: Red Cross Supplies
lender: American Red Cross, Long Island Chapter
description: A display of American Red Cross emergency supplies. The Red Cross suggests that all homeowners have an emergency kit that contains the following:  a blanket, preparedness and volunteering booklets, a Red Cross backpack, an emergency ration packet, Huggies baby wipes, diapers, an AM/FM Radio, an emergency poncho, a Fold-A-Carrier package, Scott's toilet paper roll, Emergency drinking water packets, a deck of cards, a roll of duct tape, a flashlight, batteries, a whistle, gloves, a facemask, a Red Cross First Aid Kit, hand sanitizer, and a sanitary kit.
subject: Emergency Management

title: Irene damage, Bay Shore
lender: Photos by Thomas A. Ferrara, Courtesy Newsday, and Charles Krupa, Courtesy AP Media.
description: Hurricane Irene in 2011 caused floods along the south shore.
subject: Hurricane Irene

title: Lindenhurst Hurricane Sandy
description: The streets of Lindenhurst became rivers during Sandy.
subject: Hurricane Sandy

title: Looking Backwards Part 1
description: In this video you will learn about the 1938 Hurricane that struck Long Island on September 21, 1938.  Featured are people who remember the storm including Al Grover, Marge and Bill Miller, and former owners of cottages at West Meadow Beach.
subject: Long Island Express; 1938 Hurricane

title: Looking Backwards Part 2
description: This video explores earlier storms and hurricanes after the 1938 hurricane, including the 1944 Great Atlantic Hurricane, Hurricanes Carol, Donna and Gloria, and the 1991-92 nor'easters.  Participants include Jay Lippert, Marge and Bill Miller, Bill Marinaccio, and other Long Island residents.  Also included are historic photographs from family collections.
subject: Great Atlantic Hurricane; 1991 Nor'Easter

title: Superstorm Sandy
description: This video profiles people who survived Superstorm Sandy in Freeport, Long Beach and other south shore communities.
subject: Hurricane Sandy

title: Fishing Stories
description: In this video Long Island baymen and fishermen discuss how Superstorm Sandy affected the bay and their ability to work after the storm, and how the bay recovered.  Featured speakers are Bill Reed of Hampton Bays, and Freeport baymen Joey Scavone and Tom Jefferies.The video is part of Long Island Traditions' In Harm's Way exhibit.
subject: Hurricane Sandy

title: Looking Forwards
description: In this video architects Joe Pignataro, Joe Galinaro, and planner David Sabatino discuss what the future holds for waterfront communities.  Also participating are coastal planner and former commisioner of conservation and waterways Tom Doheny from the Town of Hempstead, which suffered catastrophic damage during Superstorm Sandy.
subject: Hurricane Sandy

title: Newsday: Irene
description: As the tide comes in, flooded out houses along the waterfront in Patchogue, New York are inundated with water from the storm surge of Hurricane Irene Sunday, August 28, 2011.  Thomas A. Ferrara/Newsday
subject: Hurricane Irene

title: Ocean Beach 1938
description: Fire Island and shoreline communities along Great South Bay bore the brunt of the 1938 hurricane.  Priscilla Teich, a storm survivor recalled, her friend’s “house collapsed, all the trees in their yard collapsed, and we didn’t realize what a dreadful storm it was.”  Courtesy Ocean Beach Historical Society.
subject: Long Island Express; 1938 Hurricane

title: Point Lookout Beach Planting [1/2]
lender: Photo by Nancy Solomon, December 2014, Courtesy Long Island Traditions
description: Immediately after Sandy the Town of Hempstead and other municipalities began planting beach grass to strengthen their dunes, using the help of volunteers like Christine & Melissa Watson and their work force.  Areas that had protective dunes suffered less damage, including Point Lookout.
subject: Hurricane Sandy

title: Point Lookout Beach Planting [2/2]
lender: Photo by Nancy Solomon, December 2014, Courtesy Long Island Traditions
description: Immediately after Sandy the Town of Hempstead and other municipalities began planting beach grass to strengthen their dunes, using the help of volunteers like Christine & Melissa Watson and their work force.  Areas that had protective dunes suffered less damage, including Point Lookout.
subject: Hurricane Sandy

title: Public Works Project 1938
description: The Public Works Administration began building sand dunes along Fire Island and Westhampton Beach, using posts from fallen trees after the 1938 Hurricane.  Local residents also began making dunes using plants and bushes
subject: Long Island Express; 1938 Hurricane

title: Scenes from Sandy

subject: Hurricane Sandy

title: Island Park

title: Jones Beach Snow Fence
lender: Photos by Nancy Solomon, Courtesy Long Island Traditions
description: Snow fences are common sights along Long Island’s beaches, which help trap blowing sand and increase the dune.  Several places including the Far Rockaway bungalows benefitted from the protection offered by dunes.
subject: Hurricane Protection; Coastal Zone Management

title: Stabilization Post Hurricane of 1938
description: The Public Works Administration began building a barrier Fire Island and Westhampton Beach. Local residents also began making dunes using plants and bushes.
subject: Hurricane Protection; Coastal Zone Management

title: Hurricane Gloria
lender: Newsday; Photo by J. Michael Dombrowski
description: On Sunrise Highway, telephone lines and telephone poles almost stopped this car from proceeding as a result of Hurricane Gloria. (Sept. 1985).

title: Sag Harbor Whaler's Church
description: The steeple of the Old Whaler’s Church in Sag Harbor blew off during the 1938 Hurricane.  It took many years to fully rebuild it, but today it remains intact.

title: Coastal Village Interactive Design Table
description: Visitors to the museum were encouraged to create their own coastal waterfront village.

title: Friends of Freeport
description:
Immediately after Sandy several community based groups were created to assist their neighbors.  The Friends of Freeport has assisted over 400 homeowners and residents, gutting and reframing damaged houses, removing trees and mold, and providing meals and clothes to those left homeless. The hazmat suit was essential for the volunteers.
“A lot of people got depressed and had to move out. We had to pull out the walls, sheetrock, and insulation.” – Lois Howes

title: Groin construction
description: Groin under construction at Point Lookout c 1944
